name: Magic Duels
description: MORE CARDS. MORE STRATEGY. BIGGER STORY. Collect 1,300+ earnable cards, battle in 60+ single-player campaign missions, and emerge victorious in epic online duels.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 8/7 (XP not supported) Processor: 2GHz CPU (Pentium 4 or equivalent) Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: 512MB DirectX 11.0 compatible video card with Pixelshader 3.0 support DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 2500 MB available space Sound Card: DirectX 11.0 compatible sound card Additional Notes: 1GB RAM (2GB for Windows 7)

reviews.review_text: I think I was one of the people who didn't have a problem running the game... I also played through the tutorial and got my first story quest/mission done. I really liked the heartstone vibe they gave the game. I have some cool information I was able to gather while I played and can share with those waiting for the game to be fixed:  - When you start the game you can get a free starter pack at the store that gives you 20/22 cards of each color to make your own decks and lands to go along with them.  - Right now there are 18 pages of 12 cards each ingame... so around 216 cards to collect and make decks at launch.  - First Boosters are called Origins Boosters and are priced as follows: 1x150g, 2x300g, 8x1200g, 20x3000g. Each booster has 6 cards.  - You can foil cards for 5G and it foils all cards of that type you have.  - You can get Gs ingame... first tutorial quest gives you 30g and first full main story campaign gives 150G (that's the only one I have unlocked sorry)...   - You can get Gs online by playing against other players or against bots: 5g vs easy, 10g vs medium or 15g vs hard. (I couldn't play against other players)  - The game has an option to play with a fully custom made deck or it has a deck wizard that helps you make the kind of deck you want with the cards you have (that I found quite good)  - Pricing for Gs on the store is as follows: 150g x 2us$ (1 booster), 500g x 5us$, 1250g x 10us$, 3750g x 25us$ or 7500g x 40us$.  I never played too much Magic before but I really liked what I saw here... not too flashy animation wise but functional... I hope game gets fixed as soon as possible so all can try it. Right now I can recommend this game, it looked fun and free... gold didn't seem that difficult to get too and there are lots of carts to start.
It doesn't use the official rules,  and it doesnt have all the cards in the set. But by damn is it still a better game and far less of a rip off then MTGO.
They're listening to the community by implementing new updates every set, fixing bugs and adding new cards.

After a few expansions and patches this videogame based on MTG, the best game in the world (not biased at all ;) is getting really good. Most of the huge bugs have been fixed, 2hg is now playable with steam friends, very few crashes to desktop or game freezes.   The pool of cards is getting huge and deckbuilding is more fun than ever. Even if some archetypes* are more dominant and seem to be everywhere in the top ranks, there is a lot of options and you will have to make hard choices to fine tune and cut down excess cards to make your perfect 60 cards decks.  Starting out with no collection might be hard and you will have to grind for golds a long time before you get the base for strong decks if you dont want to pay at all. I did pay as much as i would pay for a good game and im not disapointed as i have played this game for more than 800 hours and i still have fun with it.  *not refering to archetype autodeckbuilder; use manual deckbuilder and make your own.

+ You can build your own decks with no artificial limitation except the rarity limitation (a max. of 3 uncommons, 2 rares, 1 mythic rare) characteristic of this game, which actually favors variety in decks in a positive way. That means less reliance on powerful cards and more need for deck synergy.  + You can compete against other players from all over the world using your unique decks  + The game is updated with new expansions and manages to bring something new to the table in regular intervals.  + Thanks in part to daily quests, a regular and dedicated player (who already owns the backlog of cards) can manage to generate enough in game currency to obtain every single new card without too much hassle. I would also like to mention that you don't need all the existing cards to build competitive decks.  - Story mode additions are too short and threadbare.  - Every expansion brings several new bugs which is understandable for a game with so many possibilities, but the developers are a bit lazy when it comes to adressing these issues and patches are overdue.

I never grew up playing Magic the Gathering so I don't know much about the story or the lore but I did buy Magic 2014. Personally I didn't like it thought it was a bad game but this on the other hand is a completely different story it's fun, simple and free. I love card games and since there's not much good ones out there this hits the need to play a new one.  There's plenty of things to like about this game the artwork is amazing, the soundtrack is beautiful and the card art and designs are something to adore, plus the simple animations add onto it all. The game has a good tutorial very easy to understand, the user interface is easy to use and just about everything is visually helpful and appealing to your eyes. The settings are decent as much as you'd expect from a trading card game. Controls are easy and fluid, the mouse works great and so does a controller. Building your card deck is fun and in depth, there's heaps of deck builds to choose from. Designing your deck I thought was a nice touch as well, you get to choose the card deck's art, avatar and avatar background. The real gem here though is the coop/tag and the online battles they are super fun and enjoyable, it's pretty much what you will be playing unless your really into the lore which the story does a great job of providing.  Now the bad, honestly I thought in this day and age a simple card game like this would come with borderless windowed mode/fullscreen window but it doesn't. Personally I thought the tutorial was way too long and well I kinda got bored of it half way through but you still need to finish it your forced too. The battlefield or table doesn't look as good as it did in previous games but I'll forgive it because it's visually intuitive. Drawing cards still feels somewhat rigged but it's not as bad as it use to be and getting gold is grindy but still I'd take that over DLC any day of the week.  This is what they should have done years ago, it's exactly what I wanted Magic the Gathering games to be like and playing for free is perfect... no more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t downloadable content.

This game is very grindy, with a heavy bias in the quest towards the PvP aspect of the game. The base card sets are adequate, with the story arcs offering a manageable amount of coins to supplement. I'm not sure why the reviews are so mixed.   Are there bugs? Yes Is the transition to microtransactions annoying? Yes Is the matchmaking sketchy at times? Yes  But the AI players are better than ever, you have access to a breadth of cards, and can finally make your own decks. I hate the 'up or down' system. On a scale of 0.0 to 10.0, this is about a 7.5. If they could fix the bugs and make matchmaking not so sucky, we'd go to about 8.9. If you could eliminate (or up) the number of decks you can store from 30 to at least 50. that would bump us up to around 9.4.  Read other reviews and draw your own conclusions. If you feel strongly about other elements (like microtransactions) then stay away. On microtransaction -- if you play the game a lot, you get a goodly number of 'free' coins to offset, in my opinion.  The mechanics and the ability to play a decent AI are important to me (I can't always play with a human because I get interrupted). Those work pretty well. If you understand how complex M:TG is, this is no small accomplishment.

This game was pretty buggy when it first came out. I dropped it and only recently picked it up again. Here are my thoughts. I'll start off with a TLDR and then explain in detail afterwards.  Overall thoughts: Get this game if you like Magic, you won't regret it.  Pros: It's Magic for free.  Interface is well done and easy to pick up.  Multiplayer matchmaking is quick and games are fluid and fun.   Boosters award cards intelligently, and will not give you more cards than the legal allowed amount.  Cons:  The game still suffers random crashes.  No Draft modes/limited multiplayer modes.  In detail now.  Pros:  It's Magic for free. Unlike previous DotP games, the sets that are relased in this game are closely tied to the actual sets that are released in paper. You don't have to pay money for it and everything in game can be earned through the in-game currency. This by itself should merit a download if you enjoy the card game.  Interface is well done and easy to pick up. The game is chok full of step-by-step interactive tutorials as well as exclusive story mode campaigns for every expansion release. Unlike magic online, every action in game is very clearly explained to you and the very basics of the game is narrated to you as well. Anyone new to the game can learn everything there is to know without trouble.  Multiplayer matchmaking is quick and games are fluid and fun. Enough said.  Boosters award cards intelligently, and will not give you more cards than the legal allowed amount. So once you pick up four copies of a card, you won't get any more copies of that card. and once you complete the full set, that set will not longer be available for purchase. Thus, every booster will always increase your collection in a useful manner.  Cons:  The game still suffers random crashes, and if this happens, you will lose your progress, which is particularly relevant for daily quests. If you were close to finishing a daily, all of the progress made in that game will be gone. Thankfully, this hasn't happened that much for me, but it has happened. I think developers are actively working to minimize such occurances.  No Draft modes/limited multiplayer modes. This is a very minor nitpick to be honest. There are 3rd party apps you can use to simulate drafts and with a small group of players you can emulate this off game and construct the drafted deck in-game to play. This applies to most other 1v1 alternative game modes. This however requires you to own the full collection of cards so you can actually construct the deck you drafted. That said, this is actually easier to do than most games due to the way boosters handle duplicates.

I was very patient before reviewing magic duels, and now, after playing it for 200+ hours since day 1, and fully unlocking the entire current library of cards, I feel ready to say that I full recommend this game.   For the unversed, Magic: The Gathering is one of the most popular Trading Card Games of all time. The game itself is excellent and popular for a reason, and I love it, so I won't spend time on what the game is. There's plenty of material available online about this game. That said, I think if you enjoy TCG's in general, magic is the best one out there.  The game itself has had a very rocky road, as evidenced by the 'Mixed' reviews on Steam. The fact that the game was free to play encouraged me to stick with it, and I have yet to spend any money on the game. Now, however, I feel the game is worth spending money on (and I plan on doing so when the next set comes out in approximately one month).  First, as is popular with almost all in-depth reviews, a list of the good, the bad, and the ugly:    The good

I don't see why so many people give this game negative reviews. Here are the pros and cons I saw:  Pros - Best deck building system to date - Hundreds of cards can be obtained without paying any real money - Tons of card variety  - Fun and interesting story mode - Brought back the 2-headed Giant battles - Daily Quests to complete  - Fast PvP matchmaking  Cons - A few bugs here and there - On rare occasion it has crashed on me  - Grinding for cards can take a while - Unplayable if servers are down  Verdict: 8/10 - One of the better MTG card games I've played AND it's free! So as far as I can see there is no reason to not try it out! :)

As a fan of Magic: The Gathering, having the ability to play whenever, wherever I like is convienent- not to mention, having the freedom to connect with friends is also nice. Magic Duels provides an exciting magic experience and is free-to-play- win-win. There are pros and cons to this game, however. Below are some of the key features of this game that I like and dislike:  --PROS:   A very easy to navigate set of GUIs that are very artistically created and implemented. The effect is that the gamer feels immersed in the world of Magic upon entering the game. The GUI, honestly looks very professional, and needs no improvement as far as I can see.   A helpful, search-powered deck-builder and card collecting system makes the efforts of strategizing and amassing cards a pleasant experience. On that note, it would be stellar if the gamer were able to search his stash of cards for key words too.   A very fun single-player, story mode that shares some of the lore of the MTG universe with fans. In my opinion, this is one of the very unique features of the game that should be explored more by the developers. The backgrounds of many of the characters/planeswalkers, the invasion of the scittering Eldrazi and the like are actually quite compelling. I recommend better backgrounds (instead of foggy purple), music and more campaign missions with each release; a map that shows the movement of the given character would be classy too.   The game's versus mode is fun and easy-to-use.   A unique take on the game. A card's rarity in this game determines how many of them one may use in this deck. While some may find this a Con, I personally find this rule balances the game more between the beginners and free-to-players versus the experienced and play-to-winners. A powerful deck is still a powerful deck, but they don't seem to be so powerful that a beginner has no chance at winning. This is why I believe this is a Pro for Duels.   The game continues to progress! With each real world set release, Duels also has a similar release. This effectively keeps the game fresh.  --CONS:   Although the background music isn't terrible- in fact, sometimes it feels quite epic- I would encourage the developers to seek more variety in the theme and motifs, else it ends up feeling like Duels is caught in a slow elevator that won't stop.   There is no economy to this game- no way to trade. Unfortunately, I believe many Magic fans may be deterred by this feature. The inability to trade and sell cards is something that many enjoy with the tangible version of the game.   There is a game mode called 'Two-Headed Giant,' which although fun is very squished graphically and tends to be a chore to play through. A sectioned background or perhaps a environment where the gamers can pan around the tabletop and zoom in/out would make the experience more enjoyable.   There aren't multiple competetive modes. This is something that will likely change down the road as more sets are released. I imagine the developers will have a mode equivalent to 'Modern' in the the tangible version of the game. I do hope the developers plan to release the older sets! (I want my Pack Rats and Necrotic Oozes! ;))  --   Overall, I give this game four out of five stars, and only half a star is given because I plainly enjoy magic. I would and do recommend this game to friends.

Do I recommend playing Magic: Duels, yes.   Is it flawless? Definitely no! And it's a big, big no if I might add.  What flaws does it have? 1. Versus battle system seems a bit unstable - sometimes you find games instatly sometimes you wait 3-4 minutes due to disconnects.  2. Strange system, which makes you continue a Versus battle even if the opponent left and the game was take over by the AI. At this point losing will also make you go down i rankings. I find this stupid that I can still lose after my opponent conceded. 3. I keep hearing and reading about the crashes. I personally didn't experience any (except maybe once), but it seems that it is an issue for a non-zero amount of players. 4. Card choice seems rather limited at the moment, but still some cool decks can be made. 5. Strange quest system. First of all you can only get gold from quests with decks that you built with the in-game deck wizard, which really narrows down your options (although is the best way for the rookies to get working decks). 6. You always get 40 gold per quest be it 'win 4 games' or 'win 2 games', for me it's strange that I get the same reward, where I commited 2 times more of my time. 7. To this point I only once encountered a quest that let me use a deck of my own design. This was also the only quest that rewarded 60 gold not 40.  So... As you can see list of the flaws is pretty lenghty. But I still recommend this game. Why? Because it doesn't cost you anything. Earning the boosters comes pretty easy (without hard-core playing you will still probably get 1 free boster for 1,5 day) and I see this game as a project for the future. It's still relatively new, I hope they will fix the server issues and versus battle mode. With time new cards will be added and deck variety will grow and so on and so forth. And if I'm hoping in vain? I can always uninstall, it didn't cost me a penny, except for my time.

As a fairly casual magick player who has limited time to get together with others who enjoy the game, I have high hopes for this game and it's future. With a decent story mode, average AI components, random matchmaking duels, and decking building options; magick duels proves to be a decent strategy game. However, the draws back may include (although are not limited to) unbalanced matchmaking (players get pitted against players who are way above their own rank), decking build issues (new players cannot truelly build a solid deck via deck wizard because it only shows some of the usable cards for each step), and the cost of booster packs (150 gold for one booster pack is a bit much, considering that is equivelant to 10 wins against an AI on hard mode, especially for players who are new to magick). That being said, Magick Duels is an above average strategy card game, considering it is free to play. I would recommend this to players who are both experienced, familiar, or even completely new to magick.

So, I have been playing MTG on paper for 5 or 6 years now, I've also played all of the previous Duels of the Planeswalkers games, so I would say I have a decent opinion on this game.  Magic duels is a perfect game for beginners learning to play Magic the gathering. The UI is simple yet effective, the cards in the game are interesting yet simple, and pretty much a very pleasant game to enjoy. (You can also be creative with your deckbuilding, like me and my friends made pseudo-highlander decks in Duels and it was hella fun!)  The game also updates it's content frequently, (better or for worse) and is totally FREE!  However, I would not recommend this for older MTG players, because of the lack of cards in the game, and the lack of depth in the game that many veterans of the game may find lacking. In the previous DotP-games, there were decks that had really powerful cards, like future sight, primordial hydra and Kozilek, the butcher of truth.   Furthermore, the game lacks any sort of variety in terms of other gameplay modes, there's the single player campaign, single player mode and multiplayer mode, but that's basically it. The only mode that really chances fundementally the rules of the match is two-headed giant, but even that is flawed. The other games in the series however had really unique modes like archenemy and planechase, that I really enjoyed.  So, to recap, this is not for the MTG veteran trying to find a free version of MTGO, but is rather a fun game to enjoy for new players, or for people who just enjoy playing a slightly kitchen table-y version of Magic.  Would Recommend.

In the previous DotP-games, there were decks that had really powerful cards, like future sight, primordial hydra and Kozilek, the butcher of truth.   Furthermore, the game lacks any sort of variety in terms of other gameplay modes, there's the single player campaign, single player mode and multiplayer mode, but that's basically it. The only mode that really chances fundementally the rules of the match is two-headed giant, but even that is flawed. The other games in the series however had really unique modes like archenemy and planechase, that I really enjoyed.  So, to recap, this is not for the MTG veteran trying to find a free version of MTGO, but is rather a fun game to enjoy for new players, or for people who just enjoy playing a slightly kitchen table-y version of Magic.  Would Recommend.

I have mixed feelings about the game.  For those who love MTG and want a free way to play online with paying for the interface that takes some getting used to with Magic Online, then this is probably for you. I say probably because you will have to play through the whole tutorial (took me about 45 minutes to skip through) and every time you play and are introduced to a new game concept such as lifelink, you will be prompted (though not required) to play a 'skills test' that teaches you how to use the ability strategically.  For those new to the game and enjoyed Hearthstone, but want to play Magic: The Gathering, this is a great start. Keep in mind that Magic will be slower paced than Hearthstone simply because it is a more complex and, in my opinion, rich game offering greater variety of custimization and play-style.  For those who have played before and want a way to play online, you will have to deal with the tutorial and some minor annoyances like that for your first couple hours.  A few notes about complaints with this game:  1. The Deck Wizard - the deck wizard will limit your selection of cards to fit a number of distinct recommended themes for each deck you build to have a cohesive strategy. This doesn't always work for a competitive deck to play online because it ignores converted mana cost, for example. But it is a great way to learn how to deck build.  2. Quests - you can only complete quests that ask you to win games with certain archetypes (like a blue/black deck) using decks built with the deck wizard. I personally find this annoying and HOPE IT CAN BE CHANGED TO INCLUDE CUSTOM DECKS FOR QUESTS, but I can appreciate that Wizards is using this game for new players more than catering to old players.  3. Playing Online - I experienced an inability to play online until about a week ago (beginning of October). Since then I can play online no problem - zero server errors or connection problems. I believe the problem has been fixed, though this may just be my experience.  4. Graphic Errors - I have never experienced any problems with graphics. I'm running everything maxed and it looks very nice. Cut-scenes are horrible though, but oh well. I'm just happy to see cards come to life :)  5. Coin Cap - I personally have never met a coin gap and I play online all the time, sometimes making two boosters a day without paying any outside currency. I still have never paid to play this game.  Without paying any money I have been able to build a fun and somewhat competitive Elf based deck with Nissa and Shaman of the Pack with Jagged-Scar Archers and Lys Alana Huntmaster. It's a lot of fun.  I hope this has been helpful. I personally think a lot of this game's criticism comes from people who just don't understand how to play the game. I meet people who play online all the time that just don't know what they're doing and I can imagine that might lead to upset feelings.

A pale shadow of the real game, but it's still Magic: The Gathering.  If you haven't played the card game, this does a fine job of teaching everything you need to know to start playing for real. In fact, it's still worth a shot even if you're a seasoned veteran; the smooth UI and lack of bugs make it an enjoyable playthrough. However, what keeps it from being good is the lack of complexity or end goal. I hope that new expansions add enough content to keep it fun, especially by improving the online environment. In the end, the core concepts of the game make even a stripped down version enjoyable, and this iteration of an online edition feels relatively well-done.

Yes it has some bugs and glitches, and the UI could be a little better, but I never run into any major issues in almost 50 hours of gameplay, and it is still MTG. This game is 'de facto' the best free CCG out there, when it comes to strategic depth and artwork, which are, in my opinion, the definitive features of the genre.  And yes, if you are an experienced player and can't enjoy the game without getting all the rare cards right away, acquiring new cards will seem tedious and/or expensive. But, if you are like me and even a deck consisting mostly of commons, with a pinch of imagination, can be something exciting for you to play, then just keep an eye on your quests and you'll have a steady stream of booster packs, just enough to spice up your decks, and, eventually, even more than you would be able to squeeze in. And you can build as many decks as you want. And all of that for free.  Some people are saying that AI is OP, others - that it is way too stupid. For me that's a sign, that it is actually really good, and to be honest I was quite impressed both by the cunning, effective moves it pulls out, and non-obvious mistakes it makes. I wish more games had such an entertaining AI.  It seems that the bulk of the negative reviews comes from MTG veterans, who expect this game to give them everything they ever wanted or imagined for free, and that overwhelming negativity drives off the beginners and casual players, who are the actual target audience here. Magic Duels isn't for everyone. But it's definetly for Magic fans like me who doesn't want to make overtime to have a competitive deck. Gold is pretty easily made compared to other games. Though not given away because they still want to make some money at some point and content is easily unlockable.   Once you get the maximum number of cards you can get (4 common, 3 uncommuns, 2 rares, 1 mythic) You're never getting it again. So there's a maximum number of packs you can buy and you don't have to deal with useless copies.   Gold is earned as followed. You can play VS. AI to get 5,10,15g for Easy,Medium,Hard AI respectively and you get 20g for a VS Player win. There's some Daily quest which can give anywhere from 20 - 60g. there's a 400g gold cap (Quest doesn't count toward gold cap) (at the time of the review there's a random bug and the gold cap won't reset someday but it's usually back the day after.  For the moment, there's only 3 modes you can play. Vs player, Vs AI, And 2 headed giant (2 vs 2) The AI is 'Decent' sometime it's dumb but the fact that it gets all the cards makes it win from time to time.  There's only 1 set of cards for the moment but it's been confirmed every paper set they releases will be added in part (70-80%) in the game for players to buy with in game currency and real money. So the pool of card, even if limited for the moment, will probably get way bigger eventually.  And the question everyone is asking of course... IS IT PAY TO WIN??? The answer isn't simple. Magic by definition as always been a Pay to Win game. The more cards you get the more option you have the better deck you can make. In this game... It's controlled by the fact you can't make a 'all mythic and rare deck' Since you can easily unlock all the content (Of course it's gonna take longer for free players) You can always compete at the highest level. I personally get my gold from AI and i'll jump to PVP when i'm happy with my main deck.   So Overall. Card arts are amazing. Gameplay is pretty good. AI is a decent adversary (though you will win way more than you lose if you're a veteran) 2HG Is pretty fun in CO-OP there's no in game chat though so get a friend from your steam list or skype or just deal with the persons decision.

I was waiting for the right kind of MtG implementation from Stainless. And this is it.  Look at all these negative reviews and assume usual day-one MMO server faults. Now, neglect these reviews as irrelevant, because the game itself is beautiful, well-polished, fascinating MtG experience. = Stainless really got the hang of it through previous iterations (see 'Duels of the Planeswalkers' series) and delivered finished product. Interface is slickier than ever, every inch of your screen is used wisely. Fonts are sharp, lines are thin and curvy, cards are beautiful (as always). Gameplay-wise there's new tutorial-like experience right inside your usual match, when you see some new mechanics and have a choice to launch voice-narrated practical tutorial for it. After short tutorial and one-turn challenge, you return to your match seamlessly. Also, two-headed giant mode is welcome addition to usual choice of battle types. Deck-builder is one of the most memorable features of MDO. Not only you can choose either to have an assistance in your new killer-deck construction or pick every single card yourself (with greatly-customizable filters to use). You can also design your deck's look (character, background and name)! Pricing. Some folk here have used pricing as a negative aspect (the game is f2p after all). I say: 'What pricing?'. There's no need in purchasing anything so far. You get 2 regular quests (e.g. 'win 4 duels with green-white deck - get 40 gold') and 1 community wide (for now it's 'complete Liliana Vess campaign 35000 times', which is close to completion btw). You get gold for every single duel/battle so buying booster packs without spending RM is not a problem. = PS. Yes, there are still server side outages from time to time but it's getting better every hour in my experience. If you are a Magician, wanting a fix (a long and pleasant one, at that) or just a fan of trading card games, who never played anything more complex than HS, look no more. Go and play Duels now.

Instead of crying about (temporary) connection issues like everyone else, I'm going to try and give an objective review. I'm also going to be comparing the model itself to Hearthstone, as it's clear that this is intended to be a competitor.  This game is clearly an attempt to compete with Blizzard's Hearthstone. This is good, considering that if you look at pure numbers, Hearthstone is a terrible TCG. As far as digital TCGs go, this is a fantastic attempt. There are a few things that it's missing, mainly an ability to work towards specific cards. Hearthstone's mechanic of 'disenchanting' cards to craft new ones is fantastic, and allows for you to weed out the abolute trash you will more than likely get out of a booster and turn it into something useful. In my limited MTG experience, I've found I prefer certain colors, and the ability to turn multiple cards of one color into a specific card of another color, for example, would be welcome. I haven't run into a situation where I have more than four of one specific card, mainly because I haven't been able to play for that long due to issues connecting to the servers, but I feel like buying boosters and ending up with more than four of a card could end up being a serious problem and make booster purchases less exciting than they could be.  As far as the gameplay goes, It's MTG. same as it's been for every other yearly release. Nothing to really discuss there. The gameplay tutorial may annoy folks who already know how the game works, but it's a tiny time investment (maybe two hours) that you won't have to repeat. It's particularly nice for new players, as it literally spells out how the game functions without you needing to read long tutorials or look up mechanics constantly. The biggest difference is the ability to earn gold while playing, which you can then spend on boosters. The issue is that there is a cap to the amount of gold you can earn per-day, essentially stunting your progress. Understandably, however, they want to keep people who have less time to sink into the game on a level playing field with people who have nothing better to do. This is fair.  Moving on to card selection, I really don't have anything to say, since I've only been playing MTG (casually) for the last three or so years, so I don't know about potential gamebreakers. There are cards that I've used before that it would be nice to see, but they're balancing the game around being a standalone digital TCG.  Here's a list for people who have no interest in reading: PROS:  +It's MTG +It's competing with Hearthstone +The game functions as it should mechanically +Deck Builder works great in comparison to the pre-set decks of the other yearly releases +Music   CONS: -(temporary) Server problems -Gold Cap is annoying -Card Selection is a bit small

I played MTG briefly as a college drinking game; who knew it would become so popular in the intervening years? Duels is a great FTP re-introduction to the game as an online experience. Where MTGO is an endless rabbit hole, Duels is a fun diversion. Highly recommended in its own right and as a break from your other Steam games. To note for beginners: once you become rated on a season you will be matched with opponents closer to your skill level. Check out some starter deck builds online (try the Steam forums) to mill gold against the AI, then build your decks with boosters. You don't have to pay to win, but you can take the shortcut of buying gold as well. Watch LegenVD on the 'tube to learn some sound strategy, and you'll be much more competitive in no time.  *Edit: After trying out the full-fledged MTGO experience, I can only emphasize that you should stick with Duels for fun casual play. Unless you're a tournament player willing to drop a couple hundred $ on MTGO so that you can keep up with the current meta between real-life meets, you'll have a very poor gaming experience in all regards--from the horrible interface to the curb-stomping 'community' to the constant pressure to BUY BUY BUY, Magic Online is decidedly unappealing. If anything, it made me appreciate Duels all the more.

Update after Kaladesh release:  After playing another 20+ post-release hours, I have the feeling that devs have fixed the Mana flood/shortage problem, so the game is fun again (changed recommendation to yes). What now needs to be fixed is the filter for deck building.  Original review: Usually would recommend this game as it was really fun and I like Magic. And I think this is a good implementation. But since about 3 weeks (and strangely since I bought coins for real money for the first time) I just keep on losing about every match (dropped to rank 1 meanwhile).  Reasons - Start with 2 Mana and nearly never draw more (common for many people) - Start with 5 Mana and draw nearly only Mana for the next turns (common for many people) - Opponent seems to draw perfect card combinations that nearly always work out while I draw the wrong cards in the wrong situation  The last one may be a subjective reason, but even if I go for Meta decks, that does not work out. The normal flow of a game is to attack with all (maybe deselect a few). But the 'Skip attack' button is located in the flow of button presses. It appears after the timer expires, exactly where you expect the 'attack with all' button. You click the button immediately when it appears because that's when the timer expires. This is really annoying because it's a non-reparable action. When you skip the attack, that's it, you cannot do anything anymore to attack. I'd like the buttons to be swapped. Because if you acidentally attack with all, you can just press again to cancel. Or have a separate button to skip the attack. But hiding the skip attack behind a timer has already negatively affected several of my games, where I ended up losing because I accidentally skipped an attack. Especially because you often have to click the 'Continue' button located in exactly the same place. So you hover your mouse on that position, ready to click when the timer expires. Another way to do it is not show a continue button that you can't click anyway, but show the skip attack button right away and only put it into effect after the timer expires. Then you're reminded upfront about the fact that there won't be an attack all button there. And when you do need the skip attack button, you can already get that action in and continue focus on your cards.

People keep comparing this game to Hearthstone and to the cardboard version. This comparison is rather unfair. Hearthstone was designed from scratch to be a computer game, Magic the Gathering was not. The latter has a lot of complexities that make it very difficult to translate into a computer game (for example Hearthstone has no instants, and basically nothing that you can do during your opponent's turn, which makes it a lot simpler as a computer game), while keeping it simple and easy to play, and fun. (Magic the Gathering Online is the most complete attempt at a computerized version of the game, and it's extremely complex, very beginner-unfriendly, and very hard to play even for an experienced (cardboard) Magic player because of its almost unyieldingly complex user interface and the limitations of screen space.)  People seem to forget that the Duels of the Planeswalkers series is an attempt at making MtG a lot more easier and enjoyable to play as a computer game, and a lot more approachable for beginners (and even seasoned cardboard Magic players.) It does so beautifully, and rather faithfully to the actual card game: Rather than change the rules of the game, the DotP version is made simpler by a more limited set of cards and a somewhat simplified turn structure (where you can nevertheless still do most of the thing you can do in the cardboard version.) Quite many Magic players were in fact introduced to the game thanks to the DotP series (including, in fact, myself.)  Is this game absolutely perfect? No. Does it have its defects and limitations (both from a technical and a gameplay perspective, and even accepting that some compromises need to be made in order to avoid making the game too complex to play)? Yes. Do those defects matter all that much in the end? Not really. The game is still as enjoyable to play as ever (although, of course, if we are comparing it to the previous DotP games, it's a matter of opinion which one of them has been the best.)  And, unlike previous games in the series, it's free. Why would anybody not recommend this? It's not like you are losing anything by trying it.  Sure, it still has some technical hickups and some gameplay limitations (that wouldn't need to be there), but it's still a very well-made, enjoyable game. There is zero reason not to recommend it.

The game is far from being perfect by any means. There's plently of bugs scattered about, 2 headed giant connectivty probelsm or so I'm told, some issues with hackers/griefers online, and a few odd crashes. However if you look past all that and give it a chance you'll find a pretty solid free to play Magic the Gathering game.  It does a very good job of explaining the basics of the game that any new player to Magic should have no trouble figruing out what they're doing. It contains a nice amount of tutorials that range from basic how to play to giving a quick look as to how the new mechanics work. And the best part of these tutorials? You actually get in game currency for playing through them, giving even more encouragement for newer players to go through them.  At time of writing the game just recieved an update that brought two new sets to the game bringing the total number of card sets to 4 and a starter box. It should be noted the 4 sets are not full complete sets but rather 75% or so of the set they are based off of. Supposed they had to keep you playing MTGO or paper somehow. But despite the sets not being the complete sets and limit of how many of each card you can have by rarity,there are still dozens of potenetial decks that can be built and in the very least perform decently aganist the AI.  In regards to obatining cards and where the free to play aspect comes in is that cards must be gotten via packs from the in game store. Each pack cost 150 coins the in game currency. Now this is where I feel the f2p aspect was done very well. Of course you can just buy coins for money and unlock every card in the game instantly if you so chose, but if you don't take that path or are unable well don't worry. This game is easily the most generous I've seen a f2p game be with in game currency. Every week see a community goal for roughly 60 coins, and everyday you receive a fairly easy to complete quest that rewards 60-100 coins. You can hold up to three quest at a time and you're allowed to reroll a quest once day making it fairly easy to have 300 coins worth of quests at a given time. AI matches reward 5-15 coin dependant on difficulty, online play gives 20 coins a win and a 30 coin bonus for first win of the day. There is also story mode and the forementioned tutorials that reward coins for first time completion. A dedicated player can easy get 3-4 packs a day if they grind out the daily coin cap and do the daily quest, and even more casual players are likely to find it easy to get at least 1 pack a day.  The only other thing of note is the story mdoe mentioned above. Magic's story has been fairly stechy and not on the forefront and used to be primarly told from novels found in fat packs once upon a time ago. The story mode here isn't much to write home about. The story is mostly told in a paragraph or so before and after any battle in story mode and everynow and again a very questionable cutscene. The story is mostly just a summary to begin with those inertested int he story however will find much more at the actual Magic the Gathering website. The story it's self is rather simple and gives you a preconstructed deck that changes as you progress much like the old duels of the planeswalkers games. The main appeal to the story each chapter rewards enough coin to buy 1 pack from the shop, with the very first story rewards 7 packs worth of coins for those just starting the game.  So in closing it stands as a pretty fair f2p game that doesn't make you feel forced to dump money to do anything. The game certainly has flaws without doubt but still stands as a solid and much cheaper alternative to MTGO or paper, not to mention the interface is far more appealing than MTGO's. So don't let the negativity around the game scare you away, it's not as bad as many people claim it to be. Besides it's a free download that's around a gig and a half so worst case scenrio you don't like it and uninstall it.

Improved from early on, Duels offers a good introduction to Magic and it's rules while offering a free to play experience and an ever expanding card pool. While currently there are only two sets available (Origins and Battle for Zendikar) it's an inexpensive, especially compared to paper magic, way for players of games like hearthstone to sample and enjoy a much more complex and rewarding experience.  The downside however, is the somewhat clunky interface - Magic was not designed specifically for a PC or mobile experience, so compared to games like Hearthstone its many phases can take much longer than they would in an offline game - and rather poor experience with the AI.  The AI seems to almost always play variations of the same blue/white deck full of tempo cards, and while it is good at extending the length of games, it isn't particularly challenging, especially once a player has worked through enough coins to amass a sizeable collection.  The online experience is better, although again its a mixed bag with things like searching the library/graveyard being much faster and smoother than a table top Magic experience, while things like navigating phases and responding to opponents actions at the correct points in the stack can feel wonky and require much more attention than in an offline environment.  The ranked experience is pretty similar to other online card games, where you are given a rank (in this case a number) and are normally automatically matched up with other players within 5 or so levels of the same rank. There are instances when players with a wider spread are matched, but this is likely due to lower player count at those times rather than something with the matchmaking algorithm.   It is a free to play game after all, and with that comes grinding in game currency, in this case coins. Recently the amount of coins granted for doing in game things was greatly increased, and at the new level the experience is improved. Each pack costs 150 coins and each player is capped at earning 400 coins per day, with a mission (currently of between 50 and 100 coins) available, as well as 30 coins per win in online matchmaking and a bonus of 20 coins for the first win in online matchmaking. This means with 1 online matchmaking game and a couple games against the 'hard' AI (at 15 coins each per win) you can earn something like a pack a day only playing 3-4 games.  At the moment to a player semi dedicated to playing regularly it shouldn't be hard to keep up with grinding playsets without trouble once you have the current cards, but for a new or more casual player, especially as sets are added, it will likely require some packs to be purchased with real money to be competitive or have access to all the strategies in the game.  Overall Duels is a great game in a pretty package, for free. If you have the time, money, and inclination to play paper magic, do it, Duels just doesn't (and isn't likely intended to) compete with that. But for anyone looking for their Magic fix without spending thousands of dollars on paper Magic decks and touranments, or just to explore a more complex and interactive game coming from Hearthstone or other online card games in a free to play environment, this game does that and does it well.

Short but reasonable single player campaigns.  Not quite the comprehensive Magic simulation that I was hoping for (read: containing more of the older sets) but certainly not a bad game.  Playing with your own constructed decks against the AI is fine, although expect some cheese when the computer 'draws' precisely the card needed to either a) defeat you the turn before you defeat it or b) eliminate the threat you have that will win the game next turn.  The multiplayer battle mode is a bit slow to get started. One thing that should be turned off by default when using multiplayer is the viewing of damage animations as it just slows everything down.  Multiplayer lacks a bunch of features though!  - Can't view your opponent's deck after a battle, unless somehow they get through all 60 cards. - Can't chat with your opponent (unless you're Steam friends with them already, and even then you're using Steam messaging through the overlay). - No way to track your W/L record or view the statistics for each of your decks. - No control whatsoever over who you get randomly matched up with. One duel I was level 7 facing a level 2, the next duel I was level 8 facing a level 22. Could it be that the 22 was trying out a new / less powerful deck? Sure, but they could just as easily have gone 21-0 and I'd have no way of knowing. It would be great if there was a limiter to say 'match me up within +/- 5 levels' or something of the kind.  This game has a ton of promise, and although it has hints of pay-to-win (you can use Steam wallet to purchase in-game coins which then get turned into booster packs), it's not terribly hard to grind out booster packs five multiplayer wins at a time. Some modifications to the multiplayer system wouldn't be out of place, though.

This is a fantastic game, whether you're a noob or seasoned pro! Between the clear and concise tutorials, gameplay animations, and card information, this is one of the best ways to learn Magic. Magic Duels includes all the best features of the previous Duels of the Planeswalkers games, plus a veritable cornucopia (lol) of features the old games lacked, such as: a wider variety of cards, the ability to 'buy' booster packs with gold you earn in the game (or actually buy as a microtransaction), online battles with both friends and random opponents, and total control over deck customization. New and interesting gameplay modes in the single player campaigns are also a welcome addition; my favorite so far is Liliana vs. her four demons in the Origins campaign.  I have very few problems with Duels, and most of them relate to the clarity and functionality of the GUI. For example, when assigning blocker order, if numbers appeared next to the creatures as you select them, it would be easier to tell the queue order. When making card selections as part of a spell or ability, I am often confused by the buttons 'confirm' vs. 'finish', as well as which cards are selected. The specific functionality of each button should be clearer - perhaps 'confirm [X cards selected]' and 'skip' or 'finish without selecting'. Also, some visual indication of whose turn it is, besides simply the 'opponent's turn'/'your turn' text, would be most welcome, but that's mostly my own laziness talking. Visual shorthand is often more effective in video games than text. I also wish each set had all the cards from its paper counterpart; it seems like that would be extremely simple to do, but it's possible there's a non-public reason to which I'm not privy.  Overall, Magic duels is fun, educational (at least about Magic - though I suppose you could argue for logic and game theory too), well tuned, and highly addictive - just like paper Magic! Quite unlike paper Magic though, Magic Duels is free (and it's tough to beat free)!

Magic Duels is a great way to enjoy the classic trading card game in a digital format. And without even spending a cent.  However if you do choose to go the route of not spending you'll be facing an uphill climb, as booster packs contain only 6 cards (including 1 rare or mythic rare), and with the economy in the game set up the way it is, you'll be lucky to unlock more than a single pack a day.  The enemy AI provides a real challenge without being overwhelming in most cases.  The story mode is a nice touch that allows you to engage with the backstory for each set, while also allowing you to use strategies unique to iconic myg planeswalkers which you may not yourself otherwise try out.  The deck wizard feature, which is meant to assist new players in creating certain themed decks is a little lackluster. I felt that halfway through unlocking all the cards of the origins set that my decks were stronger than after finishing unlocking the entire set. Perhaps this is an in-built function meant to encourage players to create their own decks after they've accrued enough experience. But nonetheless, it does feel somewhat clunky.   The regular deck builder could also do with more filtering options, such as searching for certain keywords on cards, but it gets the job done. It just would have been nice to search out synergistic cards with greater ease.  Overall its a pretty fun experience for any MtG fan. But I do think Wizards of the Coast could do with increasing the value of their daily quests. With 4 sets worth of cards to unlock, its a prety daunting task for a new player to unlock all of them, and try to catch up with the meta.

Making this game was a wonderful idea, many of us have been expecting something like this for a long time, and it's obvious that the creators' hearts are in the right place where development is concerned. Even if the releases are (were) a little behind the paper version and the occasional bug is found here and there, issues are dealt with swiftly, customer support is very helpful and the overall experience is very gratifying for a free-to-play digital version of this game. Some argue the downsides of the specific format used exclusively in Magic Duels (mythics x1, rares x2 etc), along with the feature of not being able to obtain every single card of the set, but it's obvious that both solve many issues in development and bring the necessary balance to each season's metagame. Honestly, other than the occasional bug (e.g. Endbringer etc) that developers make sure gets corrected as soon as possible anyway, the only cons of the game would be: A) The approximately 100 cards missing from each set, though that too is obviously necessary for the rarity balance needed to obtain the entire set in a specific amount of purchased boosters, and also to do justice to MTGO and the paper version. B) Older sets! We'd love to see older sets being implemented in the game between regular releases even though we understand the volume of work and manhours that would take, but still worth mentioning. As things are, I will not stop recommending this game, and please keep up the good work. We immensely appreciate everything you've done so far.

From what I've experienced so far:  Pros:  - Free to play - Somewhat reasonable pricing of cards. - Interesting lore about the planeswalkers - Two-Headed Giant comeback. - Nice tutorial voicing  Cons: - Fails to bring anything new and innovating to the franchise - The cards implemented are generally tedious (personal opinion, mind you) - Buggy mess (lots and lots of bugs and crashes) - Unskippable tutorial (and really long and boring) - Chapter ending animations are from the last century. - Often suffers from connection issues - You can only progress from the campaign and gain gold while online.  2012 had archenemy, 2013 had planechase. Since then it's been going downhill. True, you couldn't make your own deck from scratch; but atleast some of the cards implemented were interesting. The most interesting thing I could find in this game was thopter spy-network, imo, and even then.. I dunno, to me it just seems like the games are starting to lose the point of what I thought about was fun about mtg in the first place.  I have a deck in physical form, which, among other things, contain the card Mindmoil and the card Niv-Mizzet the Firemind. This basically means that I cycle through my entire deck, casting random spells and deal dmg all over the place to enemies in all directions. Odd combos like these are what makes magic fun and interesting to me.  Duels 2012 had some of the same aspects. I remember equipping Basillisk Collar onto a pestilence demon, accidentally clearing the entire board and gain over 100 hp in the process. Events like these seem neigh impossible with the current cards implemented. It's all just very... Tedious...  Does this mean you won't appreciate the game?  If you can enjoy competitive play no matter what kind of deck you're playing and if you can actually get the game working, sure why not?  But I can't recommend this to you.

For a MTG player, this game is not up to the standard. The options are limited, some of the cards are removed and the limit for uncommon, rare and mythic rare in a deck ruin the play. A good way to test your deck though to get the cards required, that requires hours of grinding... Poor matchmaking for online game.

You have to be impressed with how Wizards of the Coast manage to find a way to screw up the implementation of what remains a great collectible card game.  This is an always online game that requires you to be connected to progress in the single player campaign, which gives you the in-game coin to build an online deck, and the game regularly bugs out and disconnects, erasing the progress and coin you've made. Any game that requires me to be online and then punishes me because the developers don't know how to program gets an automatically downvote.  When the game works, it isn't as bad as the last Duel of the Planeswalkers. The UI is no longer designed by someone who hates people. The cash shop, if the game gives you credit for the games you win, doesn't seem as money-grabbing as the last DotP. A few single player campaign matchups still seem to be designed to frustrate. (The black sacrifice deck with no creatures with power more than 2 against a green deck built around getting counters by other creatures dying seems like a very odd choice to introduce new players to Magic.) I still prefer the straightforwardness of the first few DotPs, but you can tell there's still a good card game underneath the braindead implementation.

This is without a doubt the worst game that I have ever played. Don't take such a statement lightly; this is no hyperbole.  Firstly, the launch was outright pathetic. On release, roughly half of the people who wanted to play it could not due to two different crashing errors on startup. Additionally, there was major server instability. This had two major consequences:   since all progress requires a connection to their server, it was impossible to gain and keep gold.   despite 1, the game still checks for local data when it doesn't have a connection. Accidentally choosing to use local data (the consequences of which are not explained to the player) will overwrite all of your data on their server.  So, within the first week many people could hardly play and/or were losing all of their gold/packs. People who didn't fit into this category couldn't even boot up the game successfully. Once the servers became more stable, the game was still riddled with hundreds (probably thousands) of bugs. Here's a short summary of a few:   If your opponent leaves while searching their library, the replacement AI never picks anything and you essentially softlock.   Sometimes opponents cast spells that they simply don't have the mana for. Whether this is hacking or a bug is sometimes hard to discern, but the devs don't seem worried about it either way.   There are a number of cards that straight up don't work in the way that they read. Under very different circumstances this would be more reasonable considering the complexity of MTG.   Two-Headed Giant, the whole reason I wanted to play this game, is all kinds of bugged out. More often than not it will just fail to work and you'll have to retry. Sometimes it will try to load five people into the game and kick your partner as a result.  Sometimes  you'll start the game and your partner will be on the  opposing team . I'd say about 1 in every 30 connection attempts is a successful one.   There is a limit on gold earned per day, this is fine. What is not is that its reset seems to be dependent upon a way in which you talk with the server in an unrelated way. As in, it's fairly unpredictable. Sometimes I'll log on after a week of not playing and see that I've just hit the cap.   There are a lot of minor bugs that I'm either unaware of or I don't have time to explain in this already-lengthy review. Trust me, even these pile up whilst playing.  Worst of all, the communication with the 'community' has been completely awful. More than a week after release someone finally said a fix for the crash on startup error was  in the works . This is the first we heard the devs even hint that they were WORKING on such a fix! Fast forward a few days later, and the same person reported that the fix would take longer than expected. LOL! Some other game-breaking bugs haven't even been acknowledged by the devs. As for all the other bugs, hell will likely freeze over before they even have the time or patience to care. Perhaps after two more years of development time this software could be passable for a game...  But hey, you're reading this in the future, right? Let's say in this hypothetical world that will likely never exist, every bug and performance issue in the game has been resolved. Hooray! From now on I'll be reviewing the game as it was 'intended.'   Options

I have mixed feelings about this game. MTG by itself still has a soft spot in my heart and in a way this game works better than the previous clients done by WotC. Just the fact that we're now allowed to make our own decks is big improvement. But has the gameplay itself improved?  Unfortunately no. Game is riddled with bugs. I've had my combat phase completely skipped a few times and sometimes I am not allowed to activate abilities or stop the clock even though I normally could.   Another thing is the connection issues. Searching for a game is tedious because it seems that if either player disconnects (which seems to happen way too often) the matchmaking will just stop. Who thought this was a good idea? If there's a disconnect, just reset the matchmaking queue and let the player wait for an actual match, no one wants to press that find opponent button all the time after queue failing.  Technical issues aside, let's get to the game design. User interface is a joke! Why is the stop timer, the most important button in the game, in the lower right corner when I need to keep an eye on the centre of the game? Furthermore, if you game designers put the important UI buttons in a bad place, at least have the decency to force the steam notifications to top right for example... In the genral the UI is pretty bad (menus etc) but the actual action buttons are horrible. Keybindings are necessary in this game so thank goodness for those.  Why do I have to finish a game when my opponent leaves? Frustrating and time consuming, tedious is the key word here. And why is the matchmaking so horrible in general? I get matchmade with lvl 9 accounts when I'm 1. Also aside the matchmaking, the business model is off the records pay to win unless you are really lucky with your booster drops. Even in Hearthstone you can at least craft the cards that you want, but here you just have to wish for good cards.

I was very excitied about this game, as with the hype it recieved (and the dissapointment i felt from DotP2015) i was hoping for a game that would be great for new players and more experienced players alike. Unfortunatly, it fails to deliver in many aspects that I feel like it could have easily fixed + Is free (technically) + brought 2 headed giant back + Keeps the fun of deckbuilding and custimization + optional tutorials for newer players that are not forced on older players +Story mode that ACTUALLY goes into the lore of magic (for once) + FINALLY allows you to use planeswalkers card types  -Can be pay 2 win as people who buy boosters will probably have more cards and be able to win more (thus getting more gold and getting MORE cards) -for the momment, very limited card pool to chose from, allowing very limited style (and limited power) decks - a lot of disconnect issues, although hopefully these will be fixed soon - if not paying for packs, getting gold to get them can be VERY grindy, and some of the quests dont even work to give you your gold -types of cards avaiable basically force you into differn't archetypes based on your colors ( if your black green, based on the avaibale cards, its probably going to have to be G/B elves for example)  - Can be diffcult to find opponenets in multiplayer, particularly for 2 headed giant.  One of the biggest issues I have with the game however is that in the story mode it specifcally shows you differn't cards that certain characters will you against you (such as Alhemmerat using fog banks to protect himself to use mill cards on you) However can you use some of these cards to help amplify your decks or give you differn't styles of decks? Nope, in fact the cards are nowhere to be seen, which makes about as much since to me as this game has in general sometimes. Why bother programming the cards to use for a SINGLE campaign level, to then never be touched again, and then just decide to not let players use them? Want to use jace's mill deck or cards? Or how about the eldrazi cards that are used in Nissa's levels? Whelp sorry, even though we programmed them and their here, you cant have them.   The only reason I can think the above statement is the case is if wizards is saving those cards for future expansions and wants more $$$, which honsetly with how this game is, I could see being the case. Although this game is fun, and is technically free, I wish wizards would just go back to the design team for M14 and use that, becouse THAT was a great game, and had tons of fun features and decks to choose from compared to this. Even though this is getting a negative review for many reasons though, I will say that its still something to try out with a friend or maybe even just to play the campaign to learn a little bit of the lore of magic or something.

I have devoted a good 110% of my brainpower to the physical card game. I have cranked out dollar after dollar to receive literally thousands of cards. I have spent midnight to five in the morning trying not to faceplant into my creatures at a midnight prerelease. I have slaved over a table, building deck, after deck, after deck. I have withdrawn from society to play this game. However, I thought that it would be pretty cool to start playing online. Trust me, it's not. It costs less to get physical cards, and then those cards have the potential to be worth actual money. Heed my warning, head to your local GameStop or card store and grab yourself a starter pack of MtG, and a couple of friends, and have some actual, physical fun. Then, you can sell and trade without having to complete a tutorial or paying for worthtless cards that have no monetary value in the real world.   HOWEVER!!!!!!!!!  If you are a BRAND NEW player with zero cards or money, play through the tutorial, which will adequetly introduce you to the base mechanics of the game. Then, it is worthless. If you want an online experience with a more minimal interface and cards that ARE WORTH REAL MONEY, go to  www.wizards.com/magic/  and download MtGO. You shell out 10 dollars for entry to the game, get some cards, and then you pay the IRL face value for packs, prereleases, drafts, cubes, singles, etc. You can actually trade with people. Then, you can sell your cards to bots and get credits. Just don't get this game.

The good thing: It's Magic, the first and somehow still the best card game there is. The bad thing? The game doesn't work. At all. Setting up a 2-vs-2 'two headed giant' game is a nightmare of errors, glitches and hangups. If only it had some decent netcode and matchmaking, this would have been fantastic. Now it's just a waste of time and money. Sure, the game is free, but it has microtransactions, and it's just not worth spending money on this because you don't really get to play.

The game has so many connection problems it makes it really unusable. Since all progress in the game (ranking, gold collection) is tied to being connected, the game really stunts itself by this issue. There are other issues that seem to drive MTG players like myself crazy, .. okay they brought back Two Headed Giant.. then got rid of the chat room.. and it doesn't appear to be a way to invite someone you know/friend to play against two other people... at least at the buggish beginning stages of this game.  The connection issue, the no chat room issue, the lack of a lobby, the problems with invites.. you would this this was the first time MTG came to Steam. 2015 was just as bad, even worse in gameplay, but at least it connected. I am sorta not shocked that the game designers have screwed this up, since they have done such a horrible job in the past. 2014 was the last good version of this game. The ones before it were okay, but UI was so bad in so many places.  Steam, step in and set these folks correct for us will ya?  A veteran MTG player.

Fun for a day or two.   This is a very small game. The rules of the cardgame have been implemented well enough and the F2P model is more than fair. The problem is that once you finished story mode (which you can do in one sitting) you are stuck with randomized AI or pvp battles in order to earn the in game currency which in return you need to buy new cards.  The two headed Giant mode (2 vs 2) is completely disfunctional, usually you get stuck on the loading screen or some such. Only current cards are included, which only makes for a handful of deck styles (i.e. black/green elf, red/blue surge, white/green ally, eldrazi, artifact, etc.)  PvP can be very frustrating, since the cards you start out with after story mode are really rather weak but PvP is the by far most effective way to gain coins. Even though it's called ranked, the battles really are not. You do not get paired up with players of your own rank and imo the ranking system is completely disfunctional anyway.  Also, for everyone who doesn't like the Planeswalkers: This is not the game for you. The entire game revolves around them.  I mean, this is a nice enough past time if you have no one to play Magic: The Gathering with irl or are new to the game and want to test the waters, but other than that I'd recommend sticking to the cardboard pieces.

Honestly... It kind of depends on the audience... But their main audience is likely for people who have already played Magic The Gathering.  I don't recommend it for any experienced player. This game would be better than Hearthstone on two conditions: 2HG worked and let you finish quests and the wizard did not exist.  Stupid deck wizard. Before testing the game, i thought all those negative reviews could be explained by some reason, like bad RNG, or something. I thought.  I thought so bad.  After testing the game... story mode is not so bad. But the game IS a cash grab, even more worse than Hearthstone, which Magic Duels claims to have followed the same model. I'm sorry, but in Hearthstone... you actually have SOME GOOD CARDS to start. On here, it's just awful.  Oh, and getting boosters (By defenition, a Magic the Gathering booster pack is 15 cards, but on here it's 6 cards, so who cares!) is a drag. Battle mode easy AI are equipped with cards you would DREAM to have - but won't until you play 60 hours of those.  Playing versus players is simple - either you are against people who paid 50$ to get 32 boosters (which is 192 cards... i think i'll buy real life cards, they cost less, thank you), or either you are against the same people as you - which means 20 turns games... for pocket change.  As the game is now, you lose either way.  Oh, and there's daily quests to get coins! Yay.. or not. Because it requires ARCHETYPES deck - so you can customize it A BIT.  Honestly, i'd rather pay 10$ like for Magic 2015 to get the same type of unlocking (get a booster after clearing a story mode mission OR winning a ''random encounter'' in a plane) than this.  Only good point : It was free to test.  As the game is, I CAN'T and WON'T recommend it.  EDIT : After giving the game a second chance, i found out that sometimes, when you manage to do those hassles that are the quests... the coins they give is not always given. Just to add to the list of cons already big enough...  UPDATE (As of 2016-01-27) : Six months later, is the game better?  THE BAD  - Still not getting the right gold amounts from daily quests, or it simply erases what i had saved up to now and gives me the ''correct'' amount. Must have lost like 600 gold this way up to now.  - Hard AI as NO diversity (I do not play against Easy and Medium now.. i mean, 5 or 10 coins a game is so few). By that, i mean : Always splashes white, always play control, as soon as you know which cards do what (Looking at you, Gideon's Reproach), hard is... well, it's 15 coins. When it doesn't bug out.  - Both me and a friend opened a ''phantom'' booster. It shows the cards you got from buying... then no cards in the card collection. Kinda mad since i had finally a Kiora...  I can't believe such bugs still exists many months after the game's launch. Seriously.  THE GOOD  - Battle for Zendikar added some diversity AND some good cards that are actually usable.  - That's it.  Yes, i played about 55 hours because i had faith it could become better. The people managing this game (if there are any other than ''Mod_Chris'', because game content updates are as rare as black lotuses) could probably do much better... or just change the people managing the game. A passionate community managed to do over 3000+ cards over a few months that are all working, why can't a game company paid to do so can't?  Anyway, still not really worth it. Try it if you want though, it IS free-to-play, but i won't ever consider paying them a penny for the game as it is.

I was waiting until the March 2016 patch to write this review. I felt it would be fair to give Stainless and WotC the extra time to produce a passable game. Sadly, this has not been the outcome.  Magic Duels is a game that has so much potential, that it fails to even approach. Free to play card games are generally well recieved in the video game market of 2016, and the amount of money that well made ones make is staggering.  However, for some reason there seems to be a lack of desire or funding on the part of WotC or Stainless, or both, to put together the nessecary resources it takes to produce a functional video game.  Magic Duels has the shell of a great game, but once you look inside you see the blemishes.  Numerous bugs still permeate the play experience. The netcode is slow and frequently does not match players correctly. The game does not allow players to accomplish things that they should be able to do in a game of Magic (such as Transforming a planeswalker with an activated ability in the second main phase). The shuffling algorithms seem off. The game doesn't even teach the correct rules of Magic, instead making stupid conscessions in the name of simplification that instead only serve to misinform.  I really, really, really wanted to write a positive review of this game. I was waiting for the March update and resting judgement until they had a chance to get it released and tuned up. I have given WotC and Stainless every chance to remedy this buggy mess of a game.  Unfortunately, considering the current state of the game, I cannot reccommend anyone play this game, unless you are completely desperate to play Magic on your PC and you don't have the money to play MTGO.  Not recommended.

This is Wizard's poor attempt to ride the reigns of Heartstone's success. The only problem? It's so much a Pay to Win scheme that it's sad. I mean I have no issue with the pay option to get boosters, but the rate to acquire them are just plain atrocious. If facing against AI opponents, a victory garners 15 coins, a booster pack is worth 150. That's an average of 10 duels for 6 cards. Really? You guys couldn't just give us more to work with? The AI are jacked with decks with strategies that clearly outclass you in various degrees. Maybe it was my luck, but playing the same AI through story mode 10 times is not what I call thrilling or enjoyable.   But I will say there is one aspect I deeply enjoyed, Planeswalkers. Finally, it has only taken so many years to get this point. The custom deck builder is fun and user-friendly, but not the deck wizard, it's an abomination of a deck building alghorithm for new players.   Not only that, these Quests (which are like daily things) where the Archetype ones involve using decks from the deck wizard are utterly annoying and not fun at all. But they give you free coins if you can just grind through them. It becomes a chore especially when they are using color combinations where you have not so great cards in those areas.   There is also one other feature I really was ticked about, in the older iterations of Duels, you could stop and pause the clock as an actual setting feature for every phase. Now? They got rid of it. You literally have to have the spazziest hands on this planet to hit either the Space Bar or the Mouse button on the hourglass icon. It's upsetting and while I understand that it streamlines the experience it really takes it away from the more experienced players who want to not worry about missing a chance to react to an effect or spell.   I know I do not have alot of hours logged into this game, but that's because I play physical MtG. And this game does exactly that, it frustrates or inspires players enough to actually buy real booster packs and play the actual game. It's sad when you know that at the end of the day, that's the true aim and goal of this game's current incarnation. I just wish they had actually done some more material with actually more card options besides just Magic Origins. It's a good game to teach new players, but to keep tormenting yourself for enjoyment? No thanks.

I absolutely hate to be THAT guy. I really do. I have never before this posted a negative review on Steam; in fact, I have never posted a review on Steam period. But this game. THIS GAME.  Honestly Wizards/Stainless, you had ONE JOB. ONE DAMN JOB. See the success of Hearthstone, copy the formula and rake in the mad profits. Which you could... had this game not been a broken mess devoid of any content.  More stuff that sucks about this game:   - The shuffling mechanic is borked beyond belief and if that you don't have more lands than the average you will probably get mana screwed 6 out of 10 matches and forcing to build decks based on low mana stuff so that you actually don't lose often.  - The fact that an opponent conceding a match and leaving does not award you the win and instead gets a broken AI to beat your ♥♥♥ afterwards.  - Very few cards and tangible content aside from a very weak competitive scene.  - No tournaments at all or any sort of events (seriously the Pokemon TCG got that part right IN BETA). I currently can't recommend this game. It could be fantastic. I don't know. What I can review is the incredibly awful technical support. I first downloaded this game, achieving a pure black screen that instantly crashed the moment I minimized it. I then sought out their faq, which told me to fully update windows (less obvious), and then my graphics drivers (more obvious). This didn't help, but didn't cost me anything. I then emailed them from the reporting function on their website. I achieved: an automated reply, telling me to update windows and my graphics driver. I replied politely that I had. They then emailed me personally - three days later- asking: had I tried updating my windows and graphics drivers? I replied, less politely, that I had. It was five more days before my final response came:  'Thank you for getting us that information. Unfortunately, I do not have any other technical support to provide at this time. I have forwarded the information you have sent us to our developers. Please check back with us during the next update to see about possible fixes.'  Pathetic. I got better technical advice from nine year old redditors when I was first researching my issue. I hope this game is good enough for me to come back to, months from now, when they fix this game for me and so many others.
