Vision of a non-paying player:  This game succeeds at the 'Frustrating New Players Formula': put new players to play against experienced opponents right at the beggining of their multiplayer experience.  Yes, there is the matchmaking system based on the rank of players, but that doesnt prevents a low rank like me to play against other low rank people that have a full of rares in the deck while I can make a deck with maximum 5 rares in it by farming that few gold every day and hoping to get something good at the boosters and make a decent deck. The result is obvious: 8 of 10 matches I get stomped and the 'hidden message' in the game gradually becomes cleaner: -BUY COINS TO GET NEW CARDS AND HAVE A CHANCE OF WINNING!  Then I realize this game is exactly as the physical card game (in the majority of the cases): Wins who has better deck --> To have a better deck you must have plenty of cards to be able to make challeging strategies --> To have plenty of cards you have to spend a lot of money buying it!  At least in the physical card game I have the possibility to buy cards individually and spend less money rather than being locked to boosters and rely on my luck to get the cards I need.  In my country I have to pay R$121,30 to get 50 boosters. And now I ask you: How many other nice games could I afford with R$121,30??? And the worst of all is that there is a chance that I won't get good cards to make challenging decks in those 50 boosters, so I would have to spend even more money to have another chance to get good cards!!!  I really like MTG but got so frustraded with Magic Duels that I don't have any other option unless stop playing it and hope that in the future devs create other mechanics to encourage new non-paying players to have fun playing this Pay2Win game (yes I know that what they want is the paying players who will give them the money, but free players always can turn into paying players depending on their excitement with the game and I dont think I'm the only one who have this opinion).

What an honestly terrible game. I have played the magic card game for about 11 years and nearly all of video game versions they have released over the years. Not only is this version the worst one yet, but also a game with terrible design trends. It's like they looked at their Competition in the market and tried to copy them without thinking why those aspects were implemented in the first place. Hearthstone has booster packs with 5 cards, now so does Magic. Hearthstone uses a daily questing system and gold rewards, now so does Magic.   It makes me sick, it’s just lazy game design. The tutorial as well is horrid, even for this series of games. Ever wonder how trample worked? Well there is a god damn 5 minute long training game dedicated to holding your hand through it.   If it wasn’t free, I would say burn it. But it is free, so if you have an interest in the game and are just starting out, I guess give it a shot. Only until your eyes start bleeding though.  EDIT: Well in light of this review actually getting some attention, allow me to go through some simple pro's and con's to give some qualification behind my silly rant.  Pro's:  +The user interface is probably the best in the series. Considering the last installment's was slow and unresponsive, this is a good thing. +Plot is kinda cool, everybody like planeswalkers +It’s beginners magic, so that could be good  Con’s -Tutorial is terrible. Like really, are player’s not supposed to read cards anymore to figure out what they do? -The cards they give you in the starter have very little synergy for play, resulting in extremely basic decks. -The actual games of the story missions are fairly dull and pre-set. They are more challenges of ordering and playing cards correctly, than a real game of magic.   I have had some issues connecting to their servers as well, but that could simply be up to chance. It should also be noted that there really aren’t too many improvements since the last game. The odd thing about this is that some features that were good have been taken away. Any video game player would know the feeling of a rushed production, and this game oozes it.   Hopefully this brief break down helps some people out in understanding my frustration with an overly simple and uninspired game.

TL DR, If you have never played paper magic, don't bother there are other F2P digital card games that you will enjoy more then this. If you have played paper magic, then this game still is not for you, its like paper magic only with out the social aspect and some how more P2W.  Ok so I said I would change this review if the servers ever started working, and they have. I still cant recommend this game though.  Its just not worth your time.   The game is a supposed to be a digital trading card game, but it is not, there is no way to trade cards with other players. This alone wouldn't be that bad, but the only way to get more cards is through opening packs, which give you random cards. See the issue? You have no control over what types of decks you can make, the only way to build a specific deck list is to open packs until you have unlocked every card in the game (132 packs exactly).   Well that shouldn't be an issue, right? you can unlock packs with out paying. all you need to do is win games against other players. Right? Wrong you will win a few games against players who haven't spent money. Since you have won a few games your rank will go up, then you will suddenly start getting matched against players who's decks are loaded with the strongest cards in the game, and then you will stop winning.   Now all this wouldn't even be so bad if you could just spend $10 and get a fairly good deck list and start winning again. How ever you have no control over what cards you will get with that $10. If RNGesus doesn't smile on you and give you strong cards that also have synergy and are in the same colors then you will still be playing at a huge disadvantage.   Throw in that MTGO is still a thing and I just cant see a reason to play this game. sure MTGO is pay 2 win, but at least there you could buy the deck you wanted not just dump money into a slot machine. Also there are tournaments in MTGO, many formats and cards from every set, not just one boring core set.  A large number of players are having issues even getting the game to work at all, I am not one of them, but before you download be aware that you might be.  There is also the issue with multiplayer. If your opponent forfeits you are forced to finish the game out against an AI opponent, MTG can already be kind of tedious if you need to actually get someone's life to 0 even in a one sided stomp, and this game has you wait through a lot of timers (I see why they are needed, so players can react to things on the stacks). The end result is that you will spend a lot of time in games that are already over.  I guess a player who is trying to learn magic might want to try this game just since it has some nice tutorials, but as a game is not fun in and of its self.

While Magic 2015 was a really good game, Magic Duels falls short in nearly every aspect that matters: - included cards do not provide enough diversity - boring quests do not reward enough gold - cheating, otherwise stupid AI - manipulated matches (the failed attempt to make the game more exciting) - matchmaking delivers poor matchups (possibly due to lack of players) - pay2win destroys multiplayer - ranking system destroys fun - no reason for creative deck building  From a technical point of view: - no anti-aliasing - poor sound mixing (volume of music & effect) - Steam overlay pauses the game (also in multiplayer) - no chat, no lobbies (which eliminates the important social aspect)  I would have preferred paying for a fixed set of cards to enjoy some good, in-depth multiplayer matches. Even some pay-in one-off tournaments (sealed deck, booster draft) would have been a great addition. But instead Magic Duels is dominated by its pay2win nature and its impersonal matches. But in its current state, I am not willing to spend any money on this game.

This game blows. I'm a big fan of the trading card game but rarely play because of cost, and have played other computer based TCGs like Hearthstone and Scrolls to try a fill that void. If you are in the same boat and hoping that this will feel like playing Magic for real, you will be sorely disappointed.  The gameply is incredibly slow. Magic is a complex game because it requires interactions on your opponents turn. In order to capture this in a game, you have pauses between every card played, every phase, and so on. I get that this is necessary for PvP duels, but do I really have to sit through it all when playing NPCs in Story mode and the like?  While we are on the topic of story mode, let me just say how frustrating of an experience it is. In addition to being incredibly slow, you have to play with a prebuilt deck that you can't even examine outside of duel. Not only are these decks complete rubbish (and significantly worse than your NPC oppenent's), you have no idea what cards are included in them. Good luck forming strategies like that.  And the icing on this horrible, horrible cake is the game performance. I have a decent laptop that can run popular games like League of Legends, CS:GO, and Skyrim on low to medium settings with around 60 fps. I rarely exceed 14 in this game. The interface is really bizarre. The game table is massive, but the cards are tiny. The default option for the englarged card view is to scroll up on the card. And selecting and playing cards from your hand is awful. I've played the wrong card many times. This is the most basic feature of the game and even that doesn't work well.  Oh, also, apparently turning off the music also mutes the cut scenes. 10/10

Plus Side: +Story Mode uses real decks. +Close to real MTG rules. +Looks pretty. +A couple cool story matches.  Minus Side: -*Close* to real MTG rules, for instance sometimes tokens don't have summoning sickness. -Stupidly long load times. I mean really, how long does it take to digitally shuffle two decks? -The grind is too long to open a pack of SIX cards. As opposed to the 15 you would get in a real pack. If you manage to complete the 3 quests you get you probably can get a pack, but that's the next point... -The quests suck. They basically so far have been 11 quests to win with their terrible deck builder wizard, 1 to target an opponent directly and 1 to win with my own hand built decks that CAN win. Oh and by the way you can only abandon one quest a day. - Poor starting cards, hard to get a decent theme going to even have a chance to win even on easy. - Awkward timing on play. See each hit against the opponent one by one, but when it's time to counter a spell you cant click fast enough. Of course you get a timer each time the opponent plays a card even if you can't actually respond with a spell. - Deck building has very basic filters. Needs some keyword searching or something. - Deck building is unintuitive. Not even a 'save deck' button. They're really pressuring the deck wizards that can't deliver early game. - Story opponents are frequently given the perfect counter deck on non-final bosses. - Edit: Oh forgot to mention, after finally getting a completable quest, completion did not award gold, hence the review/uninstall.  Altogether, rather play Yu Gi Oh on Game Boy Advance still.

Magic duels is a really good card game because it is based on the paper sets which is designed with amazing care and has been improved over the years. It has a decent portion of the paper cards, but only of the newest sets of 2015. The magic rules are well implemented, I did not witness many gameplay bugs.  The game is free to play.  You begin with tutorials quests for each color, doing a bit of storytelling and explaining how the game works, and giving you the currency of the game as a reward. You are also given the standard starters decks of each color and you can build your deck entirely as you desire between 60 and 100 cards. It has additionnal limitations from the paper game on deckbuilding, the limit of 4 times the same card has been deviated to further reduces the amount of copies of rare cards you are allowed to put in the deck. For example you will be limited to 2 copies of legendary creatures. Winning matches in versus will earn you the game currency against Ai (5-15g) or human (20g) with a limit of 200g per day. Then you can buy boosters for 150g. Boosters will not give you duplicates of a card once you have reached the maximum amount of copies you can fit in a deck. There is no trading cards available. So you will be able to get 6 new cards every day for free as long as you can build a decent deck. You can check magic forums like nogoblinsallowed to get ideas if you are new to this. You will be able to build some solid decks with the basic offered cards.  You can also buy the game currency with real money to unlock a lot of boosters immediately.  gameplay problematic: The starter decks are extremely limited, you will lose a lot of matchups against human oponents that have farmed the game from the start or that have purchased the booster, wich means that you will need to grind a lot of matches to be able to get to your 150g daily gold to buy a booster, which gets quickly dull.  For example the toughest green creature is a vanilla 6/7 for 7 lands, which sucks for a green creature, and especially when a wealthy player will face you with a 6/6, renown 6, for 5 lands, nuke your board with chandra's ignition, and can drop gaia's revenge a bit further down the road. You better play agressive or midrange, because ramp is much better with booster cards.  Now the painful part: Magic games have been around for a while, and the matchmaking is still painfull to go through, it is long and buggy. In 2v2 mode you need to reset the match 2/3 because one player was not connected properly and was replaced by AI. That is especially bad compared to the newcommer of the genre Heartstone. And that hurts a lot more when you know that your deck could be much better and you are not that confident in the actual fight that will happen. The passing of turns and interupt mecanisms forced in the game add a lot of downtime compared to paper magic.  Don't get me wrong, the game is a lot of fun, you can use it to learn how to play magic and get a good idea how to build decks, staregy and tactics, for free. And you can also play it anytime, anywhere as long as you are connected. But I'd rather recommend playing paper magic with your local community if you live in a city, or buy the boosters ASAP to get you to the fun decks adn spare you the painful grind.  So actually the game is more around 32€ if you want to enjoy it.

Magic Duels is the latest and final installment in the Planeswalker games. The basic premise of the previous games was $20 Magic game on the computer, which gave you a set of preconstructed decks you could unlock cards for by playing. It was pretty limited, but a low barrier of entry into a normally daunting (and expensive) game. The games were brought down by mediocre UI that was clearly not designed with the PC in mind, netcode which was unreliable at best and a limited number of game modes. Each year we saw much of the same, maybe a new game mode would be added, but ones from last year were oddly absent. New decks were the main draw from year to year, even if many of the basic archetypes and even cards were the same.  With that preamble out of the way, let's dive into the 'new' game. The bones of this game are the same tired ones seen in the previous games, bad netcode, unskippable tutorials, a severely limited set of game modes, and user unfriendly UI. The only saving grace of this game and arguably its predecessors is that at its core, it is still Magic the Gathering a wonderfully deep strategy game. That alone almost makes it worth playing, but you are limited to running through the campaign and either grinding out games against the AI for gold to unlock all the cards, or playing against strangers you can't interact with and who might as well be AI. Playing with friends prevents you from gaining gold as does playing 2 headed giant, one of the most popular modes in the series.   So this leaves you with the 2 options, grind out all the card unlocks basically playing single player and then play the modes which give 0 rewards for playing with your friends or pay around $100 to unlock cards which would have cost $20 if this were a regular release in the series. Doesn't make a whole lot of sense as there is no added value in this release compared to previous offerings.  This game had a lot of potential. If they cleaned up the netcode, put together a snazzy UI, included lots of modes (like all the modes in the previous games and EDH), made it possible to play with friends while still progressing (2HG campaign anyone?), it would be worth playing and kicking in some cash. In its current state, it just isn't very fun or interesting or worth your time.

This game is far from being Magic. The response times are a sketchy at best, and the game does not know what to do with a stack. (Example: Opponent declared an attack, and before blockers I sacrificed my Black Cat to make him discard his only card, and in response he cast it as an instant to kill another one of my creatures. There was no timer for his instant to respond to. I just lost my creature and the rest of the stack resolved.)  This game also does a VERY poor job of laying out the different phases. When a player passes priority to end a phase the other player(s) will always have a chance to respond. (Example: When an opponent passes his main phase you have the chance to make an action, whether it is kill a creature before it starts attacking or making the opponent lose cards in hand. Not in this game it seems.) The phases also do not account for thinking out a strategy. If you have lands or instants in your hand and you have already laid down a land then the turn will end on you. It will skip your main/second phase and go straight to the end phase. I had an instant to draw cards and it was my end step before I could draw the cards and play any permants that came up. There is also no mention of untap, upkeep, or draw phases which should also has their own end phase responses.  I feel like the developers have no idea how to play magic and have only looked at some brief youtube videos of mtg. Overall I would not recommend this game to any one. Especially new players as this game will give them bad habbits and a poor base idea of mtg.  If you want to play magic online then go google magic online. It takes a bit more to get used to, but it is the closest thing to mtg that you can play virtually.

For a diehard Magic: The Gathering Fan I would barely recommend it. For people as a whole, I would not.  I'm a fan of Magic so I personally enjoy it quite a bit. However, there are a few flaws.  - The campaign can be irritating. The decks are pre-assembled and sometimes your opponent's deck is stacked against yours leading to aggrevating matches. A few times I had to play a match over and over and only won because the opponent kept a poor hand.  - The quest feature is thoroughly agonizing. Many of the quests asks you to use the game's deck wizard to build 'theme decks.' The problem is that as a starter you don't have the right cards to build on the theme they FORCE you to build on. (Even though this is mildly mitigated by the fact that you can complete quests by playing against the computer, you'll have to fight them repeatedly due to losing with your poorly made, frankenstein theme decks.)  - There's still connectivity issues. I got zero credit for winning a duel because I lost connection. (Maybe they gave me credit when I was finally reconnected, but it's still annoying.)  - Crucial moments when you want to really watch the field moves too fast. During combat there's a lot of tense watching. When to attack, when the opposing side blocks, it's hard to tell when you can respond with your instances and abilities. A lot of the time the phase moves too fast and I miss my timing to make counterplays.  Gripes aside it's still Magic game. If you like Magic I'm sure you'll enjoy it on some level. But drawbacks can be tiresome and rage-inducing.

I've been playing for a while now, and I played many hours of the previous Duels of the Planeswalkers games, at the game's urging I am finally writing a review.  Pros:  If you are a fan of MtG, and want to play an online version, this is the best-looking interface out there by far.  It is free-to-play, and daily quests and rewards for multiplayer victories allow you to buy boosters at a pretty steady pace, even if you spend no money. You could even grind against the AI if you wish to do so.  They are releasing content that is contained in the current paper magic sets, which is pretty cool. They slipped up with Oath of the Gatewatch, choosing not to release it at all until the release of Shadows over Innistrad, but perhaps going into the future they'll consistently release content contemporaneous with the paper sets.  Cons:   The game is pretty buggy. Multiplayer can lock up quite a bit when it looks for a new player. Most frustratingly, there are points when you cannot exit matchmaking if its taking way longer than is acceptable, forcing you to close the program entirely. I was unable to even play single player matches after the latest update until I learned that in order to make it work properly I had to delete all my decks and make them over again. It wasn't the end of the world, but it was extremely dumb.  Whenever you go into your collection, a pop-up appears inviting you to the Magic Duels store. There is no way to make that go away that I can find in the game. Additionally, whenever you win your first online match of the day, another pop up appears inviting you to write a review about the game. In fact, the reason I am writing this now is in the hopes that I can make one of the pop ups dissapear forever, because they become extremely annoying after a while.  There is a cool feature introduced in multiplayer that when a player quits the match it gives you the option to keep playing or to exit the match, with the assurance that your rewards will stay the same regardless. The problem is that it only happens some of the time, and the rest of the time you have to finish the match against the computer (or let's just say I finish it out just to be sure I get my rewards.) Why does this happen?  While the GUI is the best that an online Magic game has ever had, it is nowhere near as good as the one for Hearthstone. The difference in animation, sound, and overall presentation is pretty sizeable. Not that it's bad necessarily, but it could be better.   The game gives out daily quests, which is good, but some types of quests can only be completed with decks made using the Deck Wizard (a guided process that does not allow you full customization options for your deck). While it's true you can cycle those quests away, IMO there should not be such a restriction on those types of quests that they don't even explain is there. I only found about it through the forums. Regardless, progress achieved in a quest should count regardless of the process used in creating the deck that fulfilled the requirement. The fact that it doesn't happen is pretty ridiculous.  Conclusion:   While I enjoy the game, I was torn on what review to give it. IMO it still doesn't compete with its largest competitor, Hearthstone, but if you're a fan of MtG, this is the most fun way to play it outside of paper. Ultimately I would only recommend playing it if you're already a fan or want to try the game out for free. In either case, though, I would not recommend spending money on it. I have not spent a penny on it and do not plan to in the near future. So I guess I can't really recommend it if in doing so, people would then start paying into it. It is not really there as a game that deserves that at this point in time. However, if you establish that you will just enjoy the game for what it is, like I do, and don't feel the pull to spend money on it, you can have some fun.  *Update*  Once again, persistent pop-ups asking me to leave a review (though I already left one) pull me back here to update my old review in the vain hope that the developers will actually read it and make them go away in the future. This aspect of the game has not been improved unfortunately, but other really annoying issues about the game have been fixed, such as the ability for players to pause the game and leave, forcing you to either remain in the game forever, or quit the game and take a loss. Also, obviously, there is more new content with the new set. I don't want to go too in depth about the good or bad aspects (as I aleady have), but suffice to say you may only find yourself getting really into this game if you are particularly interested in playing Magic (which I am), but due to the game's shortcomings and issues still unfixed after several months it is hard for me to recommend the game to general players, and certainly not to spend money in.

Okay; so it wouldn't give me the option to recommend and not recommend the game. I wanted to do both for various reasons; so let me break it down for everyone:  I would recommend because: -- It's a great way to learn Magic and test out new playstyles for the newer sets. -- It has a sleek interface and smooth gameplay, interesting stories in the Story Mode, and forces you to have to think of a gameplay strategy you may not normally use to defeat your opponent.  I would NOT recommend because: -- The game does not include the actual Origins booster set; but rather a 80% Origins 20% older card mix because the creators are so scared everyone would stop buying physical cards if they included the actual set. -- You can only buy boosters or gold for real money in the Store; and you get no discount for bulk-buying your boosters.(Though the boosters are 'smart' and designed to only give you cards you don't have to complete your collection). -- After you complete your first campaign (Gideon); subsequent campaigns only offer basic gold-per-level rewards; no completion of campaign rewards which makes all the hours you may spend on it kind of a wasted effort.  For these reasons; I personally would not recommend because the cons outweigh the pros in my book.

I should've known better than to think this was going to be a good experience.  Magic, in and of itself, is a fine game. The mechanics seem to work more or less the same as they have in previous games, although the 'pay to win' mechanic that permeates Magic (and convinced me to more or less give it up) is still represented here. However, the decision to go with a game that was entirely Cloud-based - meaning no local saves, and no ability to save locally when not connected to the Internet - was a terrible one, and it produced disastrous results when servers don't work. I've had numerous 'You're Offline' messages despite a robust and stable Internet connection. I even plugged it into a hardline and it still told me I was offline! That's the point where the game gets put down and never touched again. The lack of a local save function in this day and age is inexcusable.  The base game is free, so I can't tell you not to buy it, but don't waste an hour of your life like I did trying to get the bloody thing to cooperate.

So far, I cannot reccomend this game. This will be my first review as i like to try and be understanding and give games time to mature. This series has had 5 years and every single release is buggy and has issues with saves, card bugs, etc.  So far, the servers in this version are up and down due to a bug allowing people to 'buy' tons of gold on the shop without actually being charged.  Myself and a handful of others i've been chatting with have lost the 3 initial free boosters you receive after completing the tutorial. We opened them and added the cards to the collection, but the cards disspeared after the next login. The game's store links as of this review have been removed, although if you have a link you are able to get to the store page still.  Lots of users are experiencing crashes, and i can confirm at least a few cards within one hour of playing that don't even trigger their abilities correctly.   The gold and campaign progress appear to be stored on stainless' servers, which is why you can't access either of them while not connected to the service. The card unlocks are unknown, but could be tied to a local save which would expllain losing the initial booster contents (though the 3 unopened packs should have been given back..). I know decks at least are stored locally, as i got the dreaded 'Choose your save file' from steam cloud once reconnected (note that i didn't know i was disconnected beforehand). I chose local and it still had my deck, but it kept asking me every time i logged back in so eventually i chose the cloud save. This stopped the prompting but i lost the deck.   Combine these frustrations that happen every single duels release with the fact that stainless or wizards don't talk to the community at all until it's too late, and i can't reccomend this game at this time. I skipped the last years version because of issues like this, and swore i'd never buy another one. I decided to try this due to it being free and thinking ok, maybe they're going to take a note from Blizzard and make a solid experience.   As far as features go, the hold priority option is missing, which is sad as it was in the original Duels of the planeswalkers. There aren't proper beginning or end steps, but's the usual for this series. There's NO chat, so you can't even text communicate with your opponent or partners. No voice chat either.  I'll gladly update the review when all this crap is fixed, but until then either stay away or take my advice and don't spend any real money on it, you never know if your cards will stick around at this point.

It's a decent enough game if you like Magic but don't want to spend money buying the cards. Because it is free, I get why they feel that they should limit the card available, but the fact that it is limited really drags down the potential that the game has. Mana cycling is not intuitive, the deck shuffling is often very frustrating, and there are cards that would complement decks nicely that just do not exist in this format, or are not available in sufficient numbers. Duels of the Planeswalkers was a more enjoyable game design, was more intuitive and had more complementary cards (even though it lacked the ability to build.)

I know developers has to make up for AIs just not being able to put up as good a challange as real people but I really wish they would have spent more time on this AI.  Overall: SO close to being a really enjoyable Magic game. One that I really wanted to love. Below you'll find my review after a couple of games. The result was playable, but has issues with tablets. That's no longer my review.  In the story mode, you follow the origins of each of the five planeswalkers. After I finished with the last game in the first story line, the game locked up. Not only that, I couldn't get to Task Master to close the program, and clicking on close window in the task bar did nothing. Then, when I tried to restart the computer, it went black, but never restarted. I had to pull the battery in order to get the game to restart.  This game is NOT ready for prime time.  -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------   This is just my initial impression.  I'm playing the game on a Dell Venue Pro running Windows 10. Basically a Window ten inch tablet running full Windows.  The game can be played, at least through the begining story scenarios, using just fingers on the touchscreen. This is an improvement over MTGO, which cannot be played without a mouse and a reasonable sized monitor. The cards are legible. So this game is portable. That's the good news.  The bad news is that it doesn't work well. A lot of actions require double clicks, and the mouse is far more precise than my finger tips. since the game is available for other tablets, it would be nice is it used the same user interface. Also, the game (as well as the Steam application) doesn't support normal tablet functionality, such as screen rotation or shrinking and growing the screen. (Heck, Steam doesn't even let you scroll down the page without attempting to use the small scroll bar on the side.)  As a way to play a subset of Magic while away from your computer, I'd say it's usable. But it has a way to go before I'd strongly recommend it.

This game is fun, and is likely the best Duels of the Plansewalkers game I've played, BUT:  As other reviewers have mentioned there is a still lot of work to be done. Some core MTG mechanics are different than the physical game, and there are a lot of bugs. I'm not going to reiterate these, just scroll through the reviews.  The thing that is truely bothersome is the lack of draft play. The way the game is set up now makes it hard for new players to play online without hours and hours of grinding for cards (or paying lots of money for 6-card booster packs) to catch up with people who have been playing for a year or more. The game could clearly become a REMARKABLE Magic Draft game though.  I go into my thoughts on how a draft feature should be implemented below, while still giving the devs a solid cash flow. _______________________________________________________  Keeping in mind a retail booster pack costs ~$4, the draft could be set up such that:  A player pays $8 to participate in a draft. Drafts would only be available bi-weekly. The draft would have 8 players, and would first prioritize connecting with invited friends, then fill in any remaining slots with Random Online Players or AI.  Once the lobby has been set up, the draft is setup just like in real life - each player gets 3 booster packs of 15 cards, players pick one card and pass the rest of the booster around the table, etc. As Duels games have been incredibly lame for making non-randomized boosters in the past, these boosters would need to be randomized - eg, any card in the set should be a possibilty! It should be just like opening real life boosters in a draft!  Once the draft is done, the lobby is disconnected and players can create their draft deck. The player would be able to use this draft deck for 2 weeks, in a mode called Draft VS. However, if a player wants to keep the cards he drafted and add them to his collection for use in constructed games, the player could pay another $4 to add the cards to his collection. Once the cards are added to his collection, they can be used in constructed modes forever. However, after the two week period, or whenever the next bi-weekly draft cycle starts, (regardless of whether the player is going to participate in a draft or not) the cards obtained in the prior draft would not be usable in Draft VS anymore.    Draft VS is a mode where players can play against Friends or Online Players Draft Decks. - Only Draft Decks would be usauble here - It should include 1v1 and 2-Headed Giant.    If the devs fixed the issues other reviewers have mentioned, and added the draft feature, it would be an INCREDIBLY good title - and a moneymaker.

Let me be clear. I will not spend a dime on this game until the Two-Headed Giant format is truly supported. Defined:  -Less than 5% of players experiences matchmaking issues -Players receive at least 30 gold from winning a match -Players quest progress is received from each match  Guys, I love Magic. I love Duels. I think it's one of the best ideas Wizards has ever had. But you promised this feature after last year's installment lacking it, and have comletely fumbled it. Of the listed requirements, only the first has been addressed in any way.  The reason I make this demand is because I'm a casual player at heart, and so to is the core base of the franchise in previous installations. We loved Free For All, Planechase, Archenemy, and Two-Headed Giant. These formats were important to us. But this game only has coded one of these formats.  And there's no reason to play. In the previous games, you could also say there was no reason. There was no reward (other than maybe a card unlock if you haven't completed that). But because the entire point of the game was to quickly get a good deck and play Magic, it was a fun system. But in this game, you cannot quickly get a good deck. You get zero progress on all your decks for playing 2-HG.  The biggest reason this is an issue? I CANNOT INTRODUCE OR PLAY this game with my friends because there's NO INCENTIVE for them to play this game with me.  Give me a reason, Stainless and Wizards.

Updated: May 29, 2016   They STILL haven't fixed the bogus RNG... At this point I must regretfully mark this as 'NOT Recommended.' There's just nothing to enjoy.    This game  really  walks the line between recommend or not. Sometimes its a very enjoyable game that represents MTG very well. Othertimes, its slanted AI and RNG make you want to throw your computer across the room.  The Lilliana campaign, unless you get really lucky, will probably cause you to pull your hair out. And you won't be losing because you're bad, you'll be losing because of bad design on Magic Duels' design of the campaign.  It completely lacks the random feel or drawing in a physical MTG match, and with the pathetic pre-made story decks, you aren't really able to form a cohesive strategy. It's not enjoyable. The rewards are not worth the frustration the game puts on you.   You're much better off playing on Untap, or even MTG:O if you have the cash.  Even as a free game, this isn't enjoyable. Unless you're constantly playing a friend, skip this one.   Pros:   Story Mode, which explores the origins of the most popular Planeswalkers. Very cool.   Gold can be earned to unlock boosters   Boosters are also easily unlocked in Story Mode   2 Headed Giant   AI and Multiplayer options   Create your own decks   Decent production, sound, artwork, interface.   The ability to earn gold by completing quests against AI or Humans.  This is a big deal when comparing to Hearthstone, in which that game makes you play against human players to earn your gold. MTG takes a less money-grubbing approach.    Cons:   Infuriating, and annoying tooltips, that will interrupt you NON-STOP. I even tried the 'Don't tell me this again option,' and it just keeps popping up. Devs: fix this crap. Its annoying enough to make someone flip tables.   AI is clearly favored with RNG.   Let me explain:   A common trait i've noticed in all the MTG games released on mobile devices and PC is that the AI will 9/10 times get that card they need, almost every turn. Don't get it twisted. I've played numerous card games on PC/Mobile, and MTG is always the prime offender. I've played Hearthstone extensively over the passed few years, and its RNG seems truly random to me. MTG, on the other hand, always favors the AI while giving you the truly random RNG. I play many MTG games in person, and with friends online using different mediums, but the MTG games released on these platforms, by this publisher always finds a way to mess with AI RNG. It's incredibly frustrating. Devs: FIX IT!   Crashes. They happen frequently. I was on the winning attack phase for my turn, and upon clicking 'Attack with all' to seal the game, it crashed... Very frustrating. Devs: FIX IT!   No point in buying multiple packs. If MTG is trying to keep up with Hearthstone, your shop needs to have a bonus for buying multiple packs. Even buying multiple packs with in-game gold in Hearthstone results in you netting a bonus. This is more opinion, than a true Con, as im sure it doesn't matter to everyone. But it matters to me.    The Deck Building Assistant is a troll. For ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles, I used this, just to explore the feature. Between the AI RNG mentioned above, and the AI deck building assistant, I was set up to be one of the most hilarious sacrifices to the AI I've ever seen. Hearthstone heroic challenges were less slanted than the mess I encountered. It made no effort to build a synergistic deck with the cards I had accumulated with multiple booster packs opened. It was laughable.    Summary: The game has some MAJOR problems with its campaign design, and the slanted RNG and AI elements are very obvious. These problems are less obvious in the regular battle-modes vs the AI, opposed to the crushing campaign. This version of MTG is great for playing against friends who don't want to drop money on anything, but also allows everyone a chance to invest time OR money in opening boosters and deepening the game. The Interface isn't perfect, but it works very well. If Magic: The Gathering would continue to focus on this version, and polish it, and push for promotion and perfection, this could be the Magic: The Gathering Online that everyone wants, as opposed to their current MTGO which is a complete dinosaur.
